I've improved your change (fixed it so it works with 3.2, added another test case) and merged patch into trunk - https://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&revision=1431200. Thanks.
General approach looks good to me.

It might take a while to get this fully reviewed and merged, because I also plan to test everything manually.

Currently we don't have a complete test coverage for all the authentication stuff so a problem could easily slip through and cause a regression.

One problem I see immediately is `version` attribute not being set in the Route53 connection class which would cause authentication to fail.

Good idea.

That specific example - Route53 doesn't use SignedAWSConnection (yay for consistent authentication API's amazon!!) so doesn't need `self.version`.
@Jc2k Also, I'm already on it so no need for you to update the PR at the moment.
@Jc2k I've tested it, made some changes and merged patch into master. Thanks!
sorry. meant to send this PR to our own fork's trunk

Please post this patch to Apache JIRA (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD) which is an official place for Libcloud patches and we can discuss it there.

Overall, I'm against this change because it changes the attack vector. Currently, if you want to "inject" bad CA bundle you need to either have access to the filesystem or original script source code, but with this change you can potentially also inject bad CA bundle by tempering the environment.

I've not tested this, but surely I could subvert the certificate validation by attacking PYTHONPATH? And if I control the environment, I control LD_PRELOAD. Plus you still need to be able to write to the file system to dump the malicious bundle.

@Jc2k you are correct about both points (changing pythonpath and controlling ld_preload).

In any case, this is touching potentially sensitive code so I still want more eyes to have a look at it and continue debate on the official Apache channel (JIRA or mailing list).

@jdevesa Looks better, thanks.

But i'll pay extra attention for 3.2 related issues.

yes, of course. thanks

I think it would be better if it remained static, as you're now incurring an (agreed, minimal) overhead for what ultimately is static data; for perspective, that data hasn't changed since I wrote it in 2010, and I doubt it will change again any time soon. If the overhead is genuinely minimal, I guess it's fine, but I think you're adding a bit of startup delay to the driver unnecessarily.

I had this on my list for this weekend, so thanks for getting to it, either way!

Hi,
about the test, i found this bug when I am trying to test this feature, but
if you get a look on libvirt api you found:

def lookupByID(self, id):
        """Try to find a domain based on the hypervisor ID number
        Note that this won't work for inactive domains which have an ID of
-1,
        in that case a lookup based on the Name or UUId need to be done
instead. """
        ret = libvirtmod.virDomainLookupByID(self._o, id)
        if ret is None:raise libvirtError('virDomainLookupByID() failed',
conn=self)
        __tmp = virDomain(self,_obj=ret)
        return __tmp
this is the source code and than you cannot get the virtual domaine with
this method and than you cannot start the node,
the solution id to get the virtual by his name
Cordially.
